node.Generative Artist: Rachel Sheinkin, Brendan Milburn and Valerie Vigoda

node.Play title: The Droll {Or a Stage-Play about the END of Theatre}
node.Synopsis:
*

Theatre is an abomination!  Or so insist the Roundheads, fundamentalist zealots who have risen to power in a time of disease and unrest.  Every stage player in the ravaged nation has been driven underground, their only recourse to offer secret performances of “drolls”—comedic bits lifted from famous plays.  When young Nim Dullyn stumbles upon one such performance, his life is transformed by laughter.  He sets out to join the players and pursue a life on the legitimate stage.  But first Nim and his ragtag company must risk death to bring the legitimate stage back to life—One Year after the End of Theatre.

node.Play title: Arizona: No Roosters In The Desert
node.Event description:
3rd installment of the rolling premier of this gripping story of women crossing the border from Mexico into Arizona.  Kara Hartzler dramatized hundreds of interviews of real veterans of border crossing and their families.  In Chicago, Tanya Saracho directs.  Composition: Tamara Roberts, Set: Joseph Riley, Puppetry: Stephanie Diaz, LIghts: Mac Vaughey
Cast:Jazmin Corona, Mari Stratton, Irene Patino, Angelica Acebedo/Erica Hernandez
node.Synopsis: A National New Play Network International Rolling World Premier. The play "Arizona: No Roosters in the Desert" examines the intersection of border law enforcement and the northward migration of women crossing the border in increasing numbers at their peril. Borderlands Theatre commissioned and developed both the play and its translation into Spanish, by Eva Tessler, Borderlands Theatre's Artistic Associate Director. Borderlands Theatre also underwrote a laboratory workshop in Mexico City with the actors and director, Marcia Bellmont under the direction of Atonio Ocampo.  Hartzler, Tessler, and Goldsmith all attended preliminary week long acting rehearsals and preliminary readings of the new translation in Spanish.  Tanya Saracho, who attended Borderland's production, will direct the play at the Prop Theater. Arizona: No Roosters ran from August 2010 til December 2010 and will reopen in March 2011 in Mexico City. The Tucson production will be mounted again in the Fall of 2011.

node.Event description: Based on interviews with two real people, Flipside tells the story of a chance encounter between a Hartford teen named Bo and an undercover narcotics agent named Nick. Flipside integrates spoken-word poetry, narrative and original music to depict the complexities of drug use and trafficking in our communities.

HOW WE GOT ON
by Idris Goodwin
directed by Steve Wilson
Wednesday, April 27 at 7 p.m.
Synopsis: A classic American coming-of-age tale with a unique hip-hop treatment: domestic suburban life remixed. The Selector, our DJ/Narrator, samples and loops us through the lives of three Midwestern teen rappers who have yet to discover the power of harmony over discord.
Our second process reading of Dearly Beloved, a new play by Brendan Doris Pierce, presented at Unity Church of God 6 William St. Somerville MA

Zoo Logic looks at topics as various as endangered species, the experience of captivity, and reproductive challenges for animals and humans alike. Woven throughout is the story of a couple struggling to conceive. Attending the "Saint Francis zoo's annual Valentine's Day sex tour" led by the legendary June "the Penguin Lady." Bob and Helen hope for inspiration, distraction, or just a little entertainment, but they wind up with much more than they bargained for when they encounter a space alien, disguised as a little lost boy, on a mission to capture a breeding-pair of endangered apex predators.
* This script was made possible by an Individual Artist Grant to Trevor Allen by the San Francisco Arts Commission
node.Synopsis:
Zoo Logic looks at topics as various as endangered species, the experience of captivity, and reproductive challenges for animals and humans alike. Woven throughout is the story of a couple struggling to conceive. Attending the "Saint Francis zoo's annual Valentine's Day sex tour" led by the legendary June "the Penguin Lady" (played by Joan Mankin) Bob and Helen hope for inspiration, distraction, or just a little entertainment, but they wind up with much more than they bargained for when they encounter a space alien, disguised as a little lost boy, on a mission to capture a breeding-pair of endangered apex predators.

node.Event description:
In February 2010 the artistic director of Perseverance Theatre in Juneau challenged Strange Attractors to “make an original play based on a classic.”   When we returned to Providence, Vanessa Gilbert, the artistic director of Perishable Theatre, agreed to join as a producing and development partner.  In April 2011 we will rehearse for three weeks in Providence, finishing with two public showings.  In August 2011 we will meet in Alaska for two months of creation and one weekend of showings.  In 2012 we will meet again in Providence, culminating in the world premier of the show at Perishable in April/May 2012 and then will later return to Juneau for the performance at Perseverance.
"The Brand Project" is a physically-devised, company-created play based on Henrik Ibsen’s "Brand." We will explore the American Dream by examining the expansive vision of American nature and the constrictive moral code in American life.  By developing the play in two very different regions of the country with artists and audiences from both Alaska and Rhode Island, we will create a dialog that might not otherwise exist.   By using Ibsen’s Brand as a launching point, a classic play with themes of dogmatic leaders and wild nature, Strange Attractors will to question the current shift in both the physical and emotional landscape of 21st century America.

node.Play title: Hitler Was Right (The German Shepherd Is A Great Dog!· He Loved DOGS!) And Other Plays
node.Event description: Three teenage girls go to the mall.  While there, they shop, talk about boys, and learn valuable lessons about life, love, and what it means to be a friend.  There's also a few lessons about racism, sexually assaulting younger boys, genocide, and how to talk your boyfriend into bashing gays, but we should probably focus on the whole life, love, and friendship thing.

Strange Attractor is devising  a new physically-devised, company-created play based on Henrik Ibsen’s “Brand,” a 19th century Norwegian play about a dogmatic religious leader living in a village at the mercy of wild nature.  Using Ibsen’s text as a primary source, “The Brand Project” will examine the current shift in the physical and emotional landscape of American life by contrasting our expansive vision of the natural world with our ever-increasing constrictive moral code.  By developing the play in Alaska and Rhode Island, with artists and audiences from both regions, in partnership with Perishable and Perseverance Theatres, we are connecting two diverse populations with work-in-progress showings and talk-backs, culminating in performances in Providence and Juneau that reflect not only discoveries made in the rehearsal room, but also time spent as artists-in-residence in both communities.

The First Ladies Project is an original show that uses a medley of real letters, historical accounts, and imagined circumstances to examine the curious, hilarious, and remarkable position of the First Lady. Written and performed by five funny young women, this is a tale that examines our nation's highest unpaid, unelected career.

Men in Waiting (Alum Reading)
Thursday, April 21, 2011
Playwright: Don Wollner
Director: Kevin Geer
Actors: Merwin Goldsmith, Anthony Arkin, Audrey Esparza
Stage Manager: J.C. Pankratz
Total Attendance: 25

Melody thought being a young wife was hard, until she became a widow. Luckily her mother-in-law is a professional – mourner, that is. As Melody navigates the prickly terrain of pressed black dresses, well-meant advice and inappropriate outbursts, she stumbles toward understanding what it means to find someone through losing them. A sad comedy about handling loss like a grownup.

The Secret Death of Puppets (Public Reading)
Tuesday, April 19, 2011
Playwright: Sibyl Kemspon
Director: Leslie Strongwater
Actors: Alessandro Magania, Laurie O’Brien, Jay Smith, Kristine Haruna Lee, Kim Gambino, Ben Williams

How does a computer scientist hook up with a molecular biologist? He uses the algorithm method, of course. But when Elliot offers to build a computer program to help Molly with her latest research project, they discover that megabytes and microbes might not be compatible —and even the most sophisticated algorithm may freeze in the face of life’s infinite possibilities. From the author of Bach at Leipzig, a 21st-century romantic comedy about the timeless confusions of love.
Previews: April 17-21, 2011
Opening Night: April 22, 2011
Regular Performances: April 23 – May 8, 2011
Recommendation: This 21st-century romantic comedy about the timeless confusions of love will appeal to everyone.  High schoolers will find the characters (and probably the math and science) very familiar and will relate to their often complex relationships.  There are several (youthful) love affairs and some (youthful) profanity.

node.Play title: Voices in Contemporary Feminism(s): A Festival of New American Plays by Women
node.Event description:
Voices in Contemporary Feminism(s): A Festival of New American Plays by Women
In the wake of Emily Sands’ well-publicized thesis, Opening the Curtain on Playwright Gender, theater artists across the country are at arms about the disparity that has long existed between male and female playwrights.  As a positive step towards equality, Voices in Contemporary Feminism(s) seeks to instigate change first by staging new American plays by women and then by engaging artists and audience members alike in conversation about feminism(s) and feminist themes, female playwrights, the current position of women in American theater, and how we can change the status quo. Featuring plays by Lauren Yee, Mary F. Casey, and Martha Jane Kaufman, the two-day festival will bring feminist theater together with the discussion of inequity in order to propose ways in which the one might actively work to solve the other.
Friday, April 15
8:00 PM             in a word  by Lauren Yee
                        Directed by: Dawn Monique Williams
Postshow Discussion: Through a Woman’s Eyes
Saturday, April 16
Noon                        Panel Discussion: A Place for Contemporary Feminisms: Improving the Status of Women in American Theater
2:00 PM            Unspeakable Acts by Mary F. Casey
                        Directed by: Melissa Cleary
            Post show discussion: Women Behaving Badly
8:00 PM            A Live Dress by Martha Jane Kaufman
            Post show discussion: Feminism for the Next Generation
This program is supported in part by a grant from the Amherst Cultural Council, a local agency which is supported by the Massachusetts Cultural Council, a state agency.
This program is also made possible by a grant from the UMass Arts Council.

Two staged readings of...
Exit, Pursued by a Bear
during the Harriet Lake Festival of New Plays at Orlando Shakespeare Theatre. 
Readings are:
Thursday, April 14 - 7-9:30pm
Sunday, April 17 - 4-6:30pm

I'm thrilled to be workshopping and developing draft pages of this brand new play at The Playwrights' Center as a Core Member Apprentice for the 2010 - 2011 season. Thanks to a KC/ACTF award, I have brought my new treasure hunting play, THE MORE BEYOND to Minneapolis for some intense examination. Working with amazing actors and director Brian Balcom and dramaturg/playwright/mentor Mat Smart, I've been thrilled with the results. Stay tuned!
node.Synopsis: The Spanish treasure fleet that left Havana harbor on that September afternoon in 1622 was doomed. They sank two days later off the Florida Keys, scattering more than one hundred tons of silver, gold and jewels across the ocean floor. Now a treasure hunter named Tip must find it, but to do so, he will have to excavate his past. What wrecks and what is salvaged? And what do we find when we dive below the surface?

When Wally sells his hardware store, his wife Gladys is ecstatic — who doesn’t love the smell of fresh cash in the house?

The lawyer for the deal is happy.  The artist renting space from them is happy.  Everyone is happy.  Except Wally.

The fuller his bank account, the emptier he feels.  So how to be happy in a material world?  Do the unthinkable.

node.Event description: This play is a new play directed by Marion McClinton.
Original Commedia dell'Arte Scenario

World Premiere by Brian Tuttle
The Heathersby House is a beautiful museum in the heart of Boston that features a priceless heirloom art collection.  Unfortunately the museum is only famous for one thing: theft.  Twelve years ago thieves made off with $20 million in paintings.  Now three down-on-their-luck friends see opportunity where others see only empty frames.  If someone else could steal paintings, why couldn’t a trio of bumbling idiots make off with some artistic loot too?  In this world premiering comedy, everyone comes for the art, but they stay for the heist.
PlayFest is a 10 day destination event with a full production of Charm, 2 workshops and 8 readings, Play in a Day, A Keynote Event, a panel discussion and more.

node.Synopsis: This ingenious and sweet time-traveling comedy contrasts two female scientists in their forties. One, living in the age of Enlightenment, races to complete her research before her child is born. The other, living in the present and unable to conceive, arranges for a surrogate to carry her child. Their legacies collide in this “entertaining new comedy” (Variety) about the search for self-discovery, knowledge and love.

node.Event description: Playwright Eric Coble brings a lifetime rich with storytelling to his work. He was born in Edinburgh, Scotland and raised on the Navajo and Ute reservations of New Mexico and Colorado. In this, his sixtieth play, you'll meet Lillian, a painter with a wicked sense of humor who is determined to spend her final years in the Brooklyn brownstone she calls home, despite her children's best efforts to get her to move into an "A-One nursing home." With the pressure mounting she lays down one final ultimatum: let her be, or she'll blow the place sky-high. Lillian's story is vivid with brilliant imagery, big laughs, and a touching relationship that you won't soon forget.

World Premiere by award winning playwright, Trevor Allen. This darkly comic play follows Julia (a rebellious Stanford graduate student researching her thesis) and Danny (a hitchhiking teenaged runaway she picks up) as together they retrace novelist and lepidopterist Vladimir Nabokov's actual 1941 roadtrip from New York to Stanford. A series of cross country adventures ensues, as they confront their own dark pasts and discover what really causes a chrysalis to transform into a butterfly. Lolita Roadtrip will mark Trevor Allen's second world premiere with San Jose Stage Company, following the 2005 hit Tenders in the Fog.

Modern Terrorism (Van Lier Festival)
Wednesday, April 6 - Friday, April 8, 2011
Playwright: Jon Kern

The second step in workshopping a new play by new playwright Brendan Doris-Pierce. A month long rehearsal leading up to a script-in-hand performance.

Anna comes unglued in the veterinarian’s office when she discovers her beloved cat is not long for this world. Strangers find comfort and connection in this surprising comedy about pets and their people.
A world premiere production
Directed by Kent Nicholson
Part of the 35th Humana Festival of New American Plays

This short choreopoem uses movement and verse to unlock a mother’s connection between an East African genocide and a Midwestern homicide. Written and performed by Marc Bamuthi Joseph, "Chicago, Sudan" is the first in a series of works that culminate in "red, black and GREEN: a blues," which theatrically navigates African America’s engagement with the global environmental movement.
A world premiere production
Directed by Michael John Garcés
Part of the 35th Humana Festival of New American Plays

Wendy has been sent home from school with a parasite growing out of her head. This rhythmic display of family dysfunction proves the old adage: the trouble with normal is that it always gets worse.
A world premiere production
Directed by Kent Nicholson
Part of the 35th Humana Festival of New American Plays
The World Premiere of Carson Kreitzer's BEHIND THE EYE.
node.Synopsis: Lee Miller could have stayed home in Poughkeepsie. Instead, she lived a life most only dream of. Man Ray’s lover and muse, her body—or parts of it—would become iconic of surrealism, but Paris was only one stop on a journey that would include Egypt, London, and the front lines of World War II. Behind the Eye traces the path of this extraordinary woman as she discovers the only thing she cannot be: still. [Source: http://www.pwcenter.org/events.php?pid=1181]

node.Event description:
She stared at the heavens, and what she saw there changed the course of astronomy.  But when Henrietta Leavitt arrives at the Harvard Observatory in the early 1900s, she isn’t allowed to touch a telescope or even express an idea.  Instead, she joins a group of women “computers,” charting the stars for an astronomer who calculates projects in “girl hours” and has no time for Henrietta’s probing theories.  But as she measures the light of distant stars, she must also take the measure of her life on Earth, answer questions of love, family and the hope of heaven in this exquisite new play—an homage to the beauty of the Earth and the glory of the skies.
Previews: April 1-7, 2011
Opening Night: April 8, 2011
Regular Performances: April 9 - May 1, 2011
Recommendation:  The inventive playwright has imagined Henrietta’s life as it might have been, bringing her story to the stage so audiences can explore with Henrietta the heavens—and beyond, into a fantasy world where she lives out her most romantic dreams.  This homage to the beauty of the earth and the glory of the skies will thrill all audiences.

node.Synopsis: It's 1884 and times are hard at the struggling Theatre Comique.  But Vigo Jansen , DC 's most infamous grave robber, is determined to put on a one man show.  A historical trifle about life, death and the theft of our earthly remains.

node.Event description:
DANDELION MOMMA
by Greg Romero
directed by Jessica Hutchinson
Wednesday, March 30 at 7 p.m. 
Synopsis: A 100-year old woman reflects on her life through broken pieces of memory.  An eight-year old girl takes care of wayward dandelions and sees the lights inside of people.  A farm girl and a writer search for life while planting seeds in the hardened ground of the Great Depression.  The ground becomes harder, the girl becomes tired, the air becomes heavier and something new must be born.

Multi-award winning company Rogue Machine presents the world premiere production of John Pollono's SMALL ENGINE REPAIR  (CRITIC’S CHOICE-LA Times GO – LA Weekly, CRITIC’S PICK-Backstage, Ovation RECOMMENDED, Goldstar ROAR OF THE CROWD).  This darkly comic drama charts three working class friends in Manchester, New Hampshire as they reunite for an evening of drinking, fighting and reminiscing.  A stunning revelation quickly shifts the course of action, while testing the friendships and instigating a dangerous confrontation.   
Stars Jon Bernthal (WALKING DEAD, THE PACIFIC), Josh Helman (ANIMAL KINGDOM) John Pollono and Michael Redfield.
Directed by Andrew Block

Way to Curacao (Closed Reading)
Friday, March 25, 2011

Actors: Lynn Cohen, Joel de la Fuente, Stephanie Fieger, Greg Steinbruner, Ronald Cohn
Stage Manager: Hannah Hessel
node.Synopsis: Way to Curaçao begins in August 1940 in Lithuania, where Japanese Ambassador Sugihara has exactly 29 days to hand-write thousands of transit visas for Jewish refugees to go through Japan to reach the Caribbean island of Curaçao, where no entry visa is needed. More than 70-years later in NYC, a mother and a daughter who have never met Sugihara try to preserve, dismantle, and ultimately, rebuild the memory of him.

node.Event description:
Sometimes it comes down to just one thing: Bob.
Bob was born and abandoned in a White Castle bathroom in Louisville, Kentucky. The ensuing rags-to-riches-to-fame-to-fall-to-legacy-to-the-love-of-living-life tale follows Bob on an epic journey in just five acts. Peter Sinn Nachtrieb returns to Actors Theatre with a hilarious and poignant story of one man’s dream. A dream of greatness. The greatness of Bob.
A world premiere production
Directed by Sean Daniels
Part of the 35th Humana Festival of New American Plays

node.Event description: Staged reading.
node.Synopsis: Milagro finds three American couples—one lesbian, one gay, and one straight—in a rustic resort along Mexico’s Pacific coast, a paradisiacal setting where miracles (“milagros”) are commonplace and where rational expectations are blown apart.  Imagine a kind of 21st century Midsummer Night’s Dream in the setting of Night of the Iguana.

node.Event description: Full production

ROMANTIC COMEDY Last year’s hit PlayFest workshop is this season’s full production! Charm is a magical dance through the life of women’s rights activist Margaret Fuller, and the transcendalistist writers Hawthorne, Thoreau, Emerson. Funny and poignant. Tender and touching. You’ll be charmed!
Washington DC Premiere, directed by Daniella Topol

book & lyrics by JASON CRAIG
original music by DAVE MALLOY
directed by PATRICK DOOLEY
Rasputin: healer or hedonist or both? Playwright Jason Craig and composer Dave Malloy, who brought you Beowulf: A Thousand Years of Baggage, team up with Artistic Director Patrick Dooley to delve into the world of Russia's infamous bad boy mystic.

I should tell you that I’ve been drinking way too much coffee in recent weeks.
    I should also tell you that I haven’t slept in three days.
Bernadette is sixteen, on the train from her New England private school to New York City to give her boyfriend some big news. Achingly articulate about all she can’t know or control, this play captures a young woman at the threshold of vulnerability and experience.
A world premiere production
Directed by Adam Rapp
Part of the 35th Humana Festival of New American Plays
A Stage Reading of Irish-American: A Life Sentence, a monodrama by and with Jerry Durkin

As a theatre devoted to the development of new work, Mortar Theatre Company has created The Graphite Series, an ongoing series of play readings to highlight new works and new voices in the Chicago theatre community. Mortar Theatre will devote resources and support in the development of new scripts culminating in their presentation to the public. The first event in this series will be a reading of Mr. Welfare from up-and-coming Chicago playwright Wendell Etherly, directed by company member Jason Boat and dramaturged by Literary Manager Dana Lynn Formby at Steep Theatre, March 21-22, 2011.
During one of the most volatile periods in Black America, the 1960s, a Chicago tavern owner gives in to his alderman and provides shelter to some of the local homeless. Mr. Welfare is a powerful snapshot of a turning point in our history that asks questions of accountability for yourself and your community.

by Dan Dietz, Jennifer Haley, Allison Moore, A. Rey Pamatmat and Marco Ramirez
The end is near! Or at least, it always seems like it’s near. From forewarning to four horsemen, five wildly imaginative playwrights join forces with our twenty-two acting apprentices to explore the enduring promise of apocalypse—and what lies on the other side.

node.Event description:
"Losing the Shore" is a world premiere play by Catherine Rush in which Adlai Stevenson, newspaper magnate Alicia Patterson Guggenheim and several other stately characters conspire to explore new worlds while moving away from their past. This play parallels the controversial Rosenberg trails and the infamous Red Scare which creates a reflective spectrum in which the characters begin to see themselves.
The play runs from March 16th to April 2nd Upstairs @ The Adrienne. Showtimes and tickets are available at http://www.bckseet.com

Wednesday, March 16, 2011

Director: Scott Schwartz

Attendance: 14

“Feminists Are Funny” itakes you through humorous historical moments in feminist history as well as the history of Guerrilla Girls On Tour.  The show provides an overview of our famous posters, street theatre actions, and excerpts from the current comedies in our repertoire.   A new version comes out each season, which includes up-to-the-minute commentary on hot political topics and what’s new in women’s issues.

Three generations of Indian women come together for the funeral of a beloved son. The collision of personalities forces them to confront long-simmering tensions that threaten to tear them apart. This quietly poetic drama has all the haunting qualities of a Chekhovian tragicomedy—Navajo style!

node.Play title: Edith Can Shoot Things and Hit Them
node.Event description:
Sixteen-year-old Kenny and his little sister Edith are all but abandoned on a remote farm in Middle America. But when Kenny’s friend Benji starts encroaching on their makeshift family—and Edith shoots something she really shouldn’t shoot—the outside world comes barging in. Edith takes aim at growing up, staying young, falling in love and facing the consequences . . . then fires away.
A world premiere production
Directed by May Adrales
Part of the 35th Humana Festival of New American Plays

Dingo, a regular ol' guy from Oroville, gets accepted to UC Santa Cruz where he becomes a Women's Studies major so he can pursue his hobby of chasing around girls. To fund his womanizing, he gets a job at the Santa Cruz Mystery Spot, where nothing is as it seems.  
Mystery Spot was awarded First Place winner in the 2010 Santa Cruz Actors Theatre Full Length Play Contest. It was one of four plays selected for reading in the 2008 Ashland New Plays Festival.

node.Related Theater: Boston University School of Theatre New Play Initiative
node.Event description:
Evan Sanderson (BFA, BU School of Theatre) wrote "Fallujah" as his senior thesis project at the Boston University School of Theatre in the spring of 2010, and was then invited by BU's New Play Initiative to continue to workshop the play as an alum through the 2010-2011 school year.  In collaboration with MFA director Jason King Jones, Evan has had several workshop productions, and was entered into the Kennedy Center American College Theatre Festival. This production will be featured as one of  the School of Theatre's entries into the annual InCite Arts Festival in New York.
Play description: An American journalist, embedded with a combat unit in Iraq, becomes captivated by the stories of the people he encounters overseas. He returns home, but his heart cannot abandon the deserts of Baghdad and Basra. Following a powerful encounter with a mysterious soldier, the journalist is compelled to return to Fallujah on the eve of its destruction. A production of the BU New Play Initiative, Fallujah is the School of Theatre’s official 2011 Kennedy Center American College Theatre Festival entry.
Running time: 90 minutes, with no intermission

One Year Lease Theater Company presents the world premiere of award-winning Australian playwright Daniel Keene’s THE KILLING ROOM.
This Beckett-style 80-minute dark comedy is inspired by the ancient story of Thyestes and was commissioned by One Year Lease.
Impossibly ancient, shrunken, and constantly bickering, twin brothers Cy and Ed, modern counterparts of Thyestes and Atreus, perpetuate their
existence through blood transfusions and organ transplants.
As young men, their greed was so insatiable and their capacity for brutality so great, they destroyed an entire civilization. They left
nothing behind but the people who care for them: a doctor, a nurse, their wives.  They still control the universe, or what is left of it, until
their long-dead children reappear…
Part ancient tragedy, part psychological thriller, and part absurd farce, THE KILLING ROOM explores what the human cycles of greed and violence
would look like in their last iteration – at the very end of time.
Keene’s writing, infinitely subtle and amazingly complex, echoes Pinter and Beckett.  His dark humor and poetic sensibilities have resonated with
audiences around the globe and his work has been acclaimed throughout Australia and France since the late 1990s.
In serving OYL’s mission to create contemporary productions inspired by ancient myths, we couldn’t have found a better fit than Keene to tackle
Thyestes.

When Devon visits Simone for an end-of-summer sibs fest on Martha’s Vineyard, she finds her little sister changed beyond recognition. As personal assistant to wealthy and demanding trophy wife Michaela Kell, Simone enjoys a lavish beachfront lifestyle that these girls never could have imagined growing up in blue-collar Buffalo—but is all this luxury really free of cost? Worlds collide and sisters square off in this keenly-observed comedy about ambition, regret and the choices that shape who we become.
A world premiere production
Directed by Davis McCallum
Part of the 35th Humana Festival of New American Plays

Katha and Ryu have become allergic to their 21st-century lives. After they meet a charismatic man from a community of 1950s reenactors, they forsake cell phones and sushi for cigarettes and Tupperware parties. In this compulsively authentic world, Katha and Ryu are surprised by what their new neighbors—and they themselves—are willing to sacrifice for happiness.
A world premiere production
Directed by Anne Kauffman
Part of the 35th Humana Festival of New American Plays

node.Play title: Andy Warhol: Good for the Jews

node.Event description:
Kelleen Conway Blanchard's Hearts Are Monsters is a comedy with deadly consequences. Hearts Are Monsters features 16-year-old Marcy, a genius with a misshapen head and a love of mole rats, her pretty twin sister Wendy (a former child star who now debauches), their drunk and lonely mother, and Daddy's ghost. He seeks justice. 
Macha Monkey produced the world premiere of Hearts Are Monsters in October of 2010. The production was very successful. The March 2011 run of Hearts Are Monsters is a remount of that production featuring the same cast and in collaboration with Theatre Off Jackson.

“Riverwest: A Rhapsody” is part musical, part social commentary, part experiment in the art of theatre. Riverwest is a neighborhood in Milwaukee, WI wrestling the realities of racial integration/gentrification, hipster-anarcho-activism, artistic expression and police repression. It is the sister of inner cities across the country. It is the cusp of urban dialogue and theory. It is Atlantis, and it is rising.

Exit, Pursued by a Bear is a play based on one violent stage direction (Shakespeare’s Winter’s Tale). Likewise, our heroine will sacrifice it all to get out in this hilariously brutal modern revenge comedy. Part "I Love Lucy", part Jacobean revenge tragedy, part beautiful ballet, part nature special, and part feminist power ballad set in the North Georgia mountains. Exit is not over till the bears are in pursuit.

Created for and tailored to the talents of the A.C.T. M.F.A. Program class of 2011, Bay Area playwright Peter Sinn Nachtrieb's provocative new play takes a sharp and comic look at the phenomenon of multiple births. The 12 members of the class of 2011 join forces as the Framingham Dodecatuplets, 12 siblings born simultaneously thanks to the wonders of modern science. Together they form a vaudevillian troupe, exploiting the novelty of their situation through song and dance and taking the notion of sibling rivalry—and revelry—to astonishing extremes.

node.Event description: East Coast Premiere of Aditi Brennan Kapil's new play 'Agnes Under the Big Top, a tall tale'
node.Synopsis: Aditi Brennan Kapil's play AGNES UNDER THE BIG TOP, A TALL TALE was first produced in a National New Play Network Rolling World Premiere at Mixed Blood Theatre (Minneapolis, MN), Long Wharf Theatre (New Haven, CT), and Borderlands (Tucson, AZ) with support from the Continued Life of New Plays Fund.  www.nnpn.org // Against the subterranean rhythms of a subway train, an itinerant subway busker, a Liberian home care worker, a former Bulgarian ringmaster and his wife, and an Indian call center escapee find and redefine themselves in today’s America. Chet writes science fiction. His book is going well, but his magnets no longer adhere to the refrigerator, there’s that ant problem and the young woman who popped up on his doorstep won’t tell him her last name. Washburn’s tantalizingly trippy play explores the addiction, power and danger of dwelling in the imagination.
A world premiere production
Directed by Steve Cosson
Part of the 35th Humana Festival of New American Plays
A week long workshop culminating in a staged reading of Henry Murray's new play "Monkey Adored"

The Circle Ensemble Theatre of Athens, GA will present Daniel Guyton's newest collection of one-act plays: "THE DARKER PLACES TRILOGY".
What happens when The Black Swan meets Seinfeld? The World Premiere of UGA alumnae Daniel Guyton’s "The Darker Places Trilogy", that's what. Each of these three one-act plays takes place in a different room in the same home of a very troubled young man. The titles are Attic, Basement, and Crawlspa...ce.
"Attic" won the Kennedy Center/ACTF Award for Playwriting in 2004, while Guyton was a student at UGA, and was hailed by Gary Garrison, the Executive Director of the Dramatists Guild of America, as "The most innovative, original play I've ever seen... from a college student." "Basement" and "Crawlspace" are both brand new world premiere plays that will be seen this February in Athens before they are seen anywhere else in the world!
Look for this new black comedy trilogy:
February 25 & 26 and March 4 & 5 at Quinn Hall at Memorial Park
Tickets are $15.00 general admission; $10.00 for students.
Please call 706-362-2175 to reserve your tickets today!

DENTAL SOCIETY MIDWINTER MEETING
by Laura Jacqmin
Directed by Megan Shuchman
February 24 – March 26, 2011
Following a scandal of molar-sized proportions, the North Shore Regional Dental Society has gathered to debate the future of Midwestern dentistry as they know it. After NSRDS president Morris J. Morris, Jr. is caught with his pants down — and his dental drill up — the dentists can't help but question: in a field obsessed with profit over health, where morality has taken a backseat to the latest fads in composite fillings, how can a group of upright dental professionals (looking for something more... filling) actually make a difference?
www.16thstreettheater.org
Thursdays & Fridays @ 7:30 PM
Saturdays @ 5:00 & 8:00 PM
SPECIAL PERFORMANCES
First Preview: Thursday, February 24 @ 7:30 PM
VIP Preview: Friday, February 25 @ 7:30 PM
Press Opening: Saturday, February 26 @ 5 PM
Theater Industry Opening: Saturday, February 26 @ 8 PM
BUY TICKETS ONLINE
Tickets: $18 Tickets go on sale January 1
Group Tickets: $13 for 8(+)

Plan-B Theatre presents the world premiere of our resident playwright Matthew Ivan Bennett's MESA VERDE.
MESA VERDE follows two sisters who come together when one of them falls sick, allowing them to air their feelings about their mother, the way she died, the way she lived and taught them to live.
MESA VERDE is about seeing the joy in our broken relationships and releasing the past.

The Body Language project is an ever evolving collaboration between Penn State University Faculty and community youth. In 2011, the production will address the problem of youth bullying in middle and high schools. Students will perform their self-written monologues in the Downtown Theatre Center in State College, Pennsylvania.

New Leaf Theatre - Treehouse Readings Series
BURYING MISS AMERICA
by Brian Golden
directed by Jessica Hutchinson
Wednesday, February 23 at 7 p.m.
Synopsis: When a legendary former beauty queen dies, her two children reunite at the funeral for the first time in six years. Divided by distance and their mother’s mile-long shadow, Boxer and Jean banter, tease, and relive childhood memories while delaying the inevitable questions: with their mother gone, what happens next? A darkly funny and moving play about family, love and inheritance.

node.Event description: A week-long workshop as a part of Key City Public Theater's 15th Annual Playwriting Festival: Virgilia's plan to impress a local militia hero is thrown into jeopardy when the lethal virus they've arranged to purchase from a mysterious African nationalist is accidentally unleashed - on her own father. As she struggles to find a way out of her dilemma she is forced to ask herself: who hears the voice of God? And who is qualified to decipher it?

node.Event description:
Doorway Arts Ensemble and Arts Alive Theatre present the world premiere of Tether, a rhythmic drama about 15 year old mixed race twins (one black the other white). Challenged by issues of sisterhood, race, faith and love, the sisters talk back and forth to the rhythm of the tether ball, discovering the deeper truths of their young lives. Tether presents us with the beauty, wisdom and heartache of growing up. Written by Julie Taiwo Oni and directed by Jessica Lefkow, (Theater J's, Honey Brown Eyes). With Gwen Grastorf and Jade Wheeler.
TETHER runs February 18 through March 13, 2011 ;Performances: Thursday - Saturday at 8pm and Sunday Matinee at 2pm. Special Performance Monday March 7 at 8 PM. 
TICKETS: $10 for general admission/$7 for students and seniors/$5 for MC Students, Faculty and Staff. Call 240-567-5775 or order online at www.tickets.com. All performances opening weekend are PAY WHAT YOU CAN 
SPECIAL EVENTS
Saturday Feb 19 – Q&A follows performance featuring the dramaturg, director, playwright and actors.
Sunday Feb 20 - Post-Show Panel Discussion:  Multi-Cultural, Multi-Racial: Growing up in the New Modern Family In this conversation following the show, we will discuss the impact of growing up in a family with mixed race parents or siblings.  Participants include Tether playwright Julie Taiwo Oni and her identical twin Jessica Kehinde Ngo, Diane and Wardell Martin, an interracial married couple also parents of identical twin girls, and Ana Lopez, Executive Director of Community Bridges, a nonprofit organization that provides multicultural empowerment and leadership programs for young diverse girls in the Silver Spring community. Tether dramaturge Jenn Book Haselswerdt will moderate.

Production Luis Alfaro's Oedipus El Rey.  This production opens immediately following the opening at Woolly Mammoth Theatre, the final producer of the play's Rolling World Premier(Magic Theatre, San Francisco and Boston Court Theater, Los Angeles). The Borderlands production incorporated rewrites specifically written for Woolly Mammoth's production.

node.Event description:
In February 2011, The Route 66 Theatre Company presents
A Twist of Water
a World-Premiere play by Route 66 Artistic Associate Caitlin Montanye Parrish
co-created with and directed by Route 66 Company Member Erica Weiss
February 17th, 2011-March 20th, 2011
At Theater Wit (1229 W Belmont, Chicago IL 60657)
BUY TICKETS HERE or call 773-975-8150
A Twist of Water centers on Noah, a gay, widowed history teacher, raising his adopted African-American daughter Jira alone in the wake of his husband’s death in a car accident. When Jira decides that she wants to seek out her birth mother, Noah’s already grief-stricken and strained relationship with his child is pressed to the breaking point. As he struggles to hold on to and rebuild his family, a burgeoning new romance with a younger man serves to complicate matters, but may also be a saving grace. This world premiere introduces us to a seemingly non-traditional family, and at the heart of their story is our beloved city of Chicago, whose history and progress is the centerpiece of the play. A Twist of Water is a love letter to the Windy City, a deeply funny and profoundly touching story of fathers and daughters, and what it means to be a family.
Starring:
Route 66 Artistic Director Stef Tovar as Noah
Falashay Pearson as Jira
Alex Hugh Brown as Liam
Lili-Anne Brown as Tia
Production Team:
Scenic Design by Stephen H. Carmody
Lighting Design by Sean Mallary
Projections Design by John Boesche
Sound Design by Lindsay Jones
Costume Design by Alarie Hammock
Stage Manager: Route 66 Company Member Rita Vreeland
Assistant Stage Manager: Route 66 Company Member Matthew Bonaccorso
Production Manager: Jodi Gottberg
Dramaturg: Aaron Carter
Assistant Director: Hannah Fenlon

Return with us now to a simpler time;
Saturday morning, 1975.
Your dad’s drinking again.
Your brother’s writing a sci-fi novel in his pajamas.
Your sister’s dancing at a strip club and your racist grandmother
comes for lunch… on entirely the wrong day.
Everyone’s still living at home. But after today, nothing will be the same.
Or maybe everything will be the same. After all, these are white people.
By Neil Cuthbert*
Directed by Michael Barakiva
Featuring James DeMarse*, Cecilia DeWolf*, David Gelles*, Delphi Harrington*, Matthew Minor, Mickey Solis and Jennifer Joan Thompson
* denotes EST Member

Stageworks Theatre’s staged reading of the comedic family drama “The Dog Story” is this Tuesday, February 15 at 7:00 PM at the Shimberg Playhouse, Straz Center for the Performing Arts.
The play will be performed by a cast of eight professional actors from the Tampa Bay area: Susan Mills, Susan O’Gara, Mark Myers, Suzy DeVore, Trey Ryan, Tom Costello, Dana Kovar and Mary Anyan.
“The Dog Story” by local playwright Ed Stevens is one of the 2011 winners of Stageworks’ Breaking New Ground Playwrights Competition. In the play, Paul visits his last surviving aunt Mary in the nursing home where she lives. Paul is intent on asking Mary what she remembers of the disappearance of his childhood puppy; in recent years he has begun to doubt his deceased mother’s explanation. As Paul tries to stimulate Mary’s memory, long-buried family secrets come to light and Paul and his family must face some challenging truths.
WHERE: Shimberg Playhouse, Straz Center for the Performing Arts, 1010 North W. C. MacInnes Place, Tampa, FL, 33602. 
WHEN: Tuesday, February 15, 2011, 7:00 PM 
COST: $5.00; $3.00 students, seniors and military 
Tickets will be available at the door.
node.Synopsis:
The Dog Story is about the mistakes families make in the name of protecting their children and how, in spite of them, families can pull together to heal. 

In this comedic family drama, Paul arrives in town to visit his spirited 95-year-old aunt Mary in her nursing home. He wants the stubborn old woman to tell him what happened to his childhood puppy; recently he began to doubt his deceased mother’s explanation about the dog’s disappearance. His cousin Lisa opposes his plan to coax the truth from Mary, who she believes is showing signs of dementia. Unknown to Lisa, Mary believes she speaks with Paul’s deceased mother Helen. 

As they prepare Mary for her birthday party that evening, Lisa reveals a worrisome secret of her own and her brother Rickie arrives distraught with his own family problems. Shocking childhood memories and long-buried family mysteries emerge. Learning the truth about the puppy and other bombshells about his own disturbed past, Paul is devastated and furious to realize his childhood memories were based on deceit. Paul’s older cousin Frank, the only positive father figure of his childhood, helps him deal with the truth. Mary facilitates a surprising encounter that enables Paul to understand why his mother concealed so much from him.


CHARACTERS
MARY: spirited 95-year old matriarch
HELEN: Mary’s younger sister and the mother of Paul, 70s
PAUL: early 50s, a bit abrasive
LISA: Paul’s cousin, mid-30s, cheerful and outgoing
RICKIE JUNIOR: early 30s, Lisa’s brother, working class
FRANK: Mary’s son, mid-70s, solid working class guy
NURSE, DOCTOR 1, DOCTOR 2: (played by same actor)

SETTING: Mary’s room in a nursing home.

node.Event description: MERONYMY is an immersive visual performance of language, architecture and sound exploring what happens when memories overcome their containers—and how a whole might be greater than the sum of its parts.

World premier of winner of the Kendeda National Playwright Competition, a national competition from the leading MFA programs across the country with a full Alliance Theatre production as a first prize.

A ritual-dramatic enactment centered around the collected (though fragmentary and apocryphal) adventures of Dan Darkson: the Detective who Sees in the Dark! A pulp-noir, science fiction romp, collaboratively dreamed and conveyed.

In the spring of 1980, South Korea is shocked by a wave of brutal military violence against student protesters in the city of Kwangju. One young activist attempts to reconstruct the events she witnesses, wavering in the hazy space between documentary realism and traditional storytelling.

Part of the APAC 15/20s: Staged Readings of New Works.
Inside a desolate bar in the middle of nowhere, bartender Hank and his only customer, Jonas, a stranger passing through, settle in for a long evening to ride out the howling wind storm. Ruby, another stranger, enters, and over drinks the three open up about their pasts, and what lead each of them to this moment. Trapped together against the storm, seemingly innocent conversation escalates into life or death struggles.

node.Play title: Fire Work - The Global Age Project at Aurora Theatre Co
node.Event description:
Artistic Director Tom Ross created the GAP with the goal of promoting forward-looking new works that address issues of the 21st century and beyond. Several new plays selected from an international pool of playwrights will be read in the Monday night play reading series in tandem with the world premiere of Allison Moore’s Collapse.
The GAP readings are all FREE events with seating available on a first come, first served basis. Any patron who wishes to guarantee a seat in advance may do so with a $25 donation to the festival. Each $25 donation provides access to one reserved, unassigned seat in the Donor's Circle. To make a donation, please call the Box Office at (510) 843-4822.
CALENDAR
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 7:30PM
Fire Work by Lauren Gunderson
Directed by Tracy Ward
Ana and her father run a small fireworks shop in a nowhere town in an unforgiving corner of the world. When a stranger walks in and catches Ana's eye (and a glimpse of her without the requisite veil), her father fears for her safety, and the fireworks really begin. Fire Work is a love story about a strong woman, strong chemistry, a harsh landscape, and the even harsher choices one has to make not just to survive, but to thrive.

Ramsés contra los monstruos: salmos y apocalipsises (bailes con canciones y visiones para el fin del mundo) [Ramses Against the Monsters: Psalms and Apocalypses (Dances with Songs and Visions for the End of the World)] tells the story of Ramses the Stewmaker, the narc's preferred dissolver of bodies, and his lover Tito/Titus's attempts to break the many curses placed on them by the victims of cartel leader La Yuri and President FeCal's Narco Guerra in Ciudad Juarez.

node.Play title: Notice: To Whom It May Concern or Disregard
node.Event description: A shoe shiner, a street preacher and a roadside vendor get an opportunity to lift their prospects. The boost is one vacant room that is available for rent. Either one of them gets it, or they concert efforts or none of them gets the room.
A workshop of the play Right to the Tip featuring actors and design, directed by the playwright as a way of testing ideas and inspiring rewrites.
A Modern Meditation on the Icarus Story.

What happens when an Owl Moon rises? In DC playwright Liz Maestri’s new work, the everyday world veers into extremities – hot blood spurts and passions seep into a wintry landscape of cold and desolation. Owl Moon follows a group of characters through conflicts and collisions that stretch taut conventions of style and tone. Add in a talking owl, and you have a play that juggles the heady, humorous and harrowing in equal measure.

DEAD PILE
Written by Laura Jacqmin
Directed by Megan Shuchman
Featuring Chip Davis, Justin James Farley, Allie Long, Andy Lutz, Mark Minton
Jeremy is a wannabe investigator: someone who goes undercover at factory farms to film the often-horrific abuses committed within. But when he's sent to do an exposé on a dairy farm in southern Indiana, he runs up against some difficult questions about his chosen line of work. A play that forces us to look at what we eat - and what we’re willing to sacrifice. 
Feb. 4-27, 2011
Thursdays-Sundays @ 8pm
Stage 773
1225 W. Belmont Avenue
xiiipocket.com for tickets and more information

Failed poet Julian Miller demands that his son Malcolm become a writer, but Malcolm has other plans – and a secret. It's a story of the blood that binds us, wine that kills, and eyes that shine in the dark.
A New York City romance turned inside out by the arrival of a Rwandan refugee.

3 Screams is a dark, dynamic, and hilarious play centered on a contemporary theft of Edvard Munch's "The Scream." An accountant and unlikely thief who's helped pull-off the heist, Edvard, manically confronts his love-hate relationship with Munch's famous painting face-to-face. His wife, Tulla, shares a completely different side of the story—baking pastries to calm her nerves, while containing a strange, stifled lust beneath her apron. 20 years later their son, Gunnar, revisits the actual location where Munch painted the Scream and must now deal with the omnipresent power this singular work has had over his family.

The Guthrie Theater presents a Workhaus Collective production of LITTLE EYES by Cory Hinkle
node.Synopsis: In the middle of a cul de sac in middle America, two American families collide: in one house, a mysterious man approaches a single mother and her son with an unusual offer; across the street, a young woman tells her husband she is newly pregnant ... but is she? Set in the aftermath of a wild block party that changes their lives forever, Little Eyes is a darkly funny look at contemporary America — a comedy about the lies we tell, and the lies we choose to believe.

node.Event description: The 2010-11 Ruth Easton New Play Series workshop and reading of Carson Kreitzer's BEHIND THE EYE.
node.Synopsis: Lee Miller could have stayed home in Poughkeepsie. Instead, she lived a life most only dream of. Man Ray’s lover and muse, her body—or parts of it—would become iconic of surrealism, but Paris was only one stop on a journey that would include Egypt, London, and the front lines of World War II. Behind the Eye traces the path of this extraordinary woman as she discovers the only thing she cannot be: still. [Source: http://www.pwcenter.org/events.php?pid=1181]

node.Event description: This is a world premiere children's musical that is about a pivotal moment in the 1960s Civil Rights struggle.

A free adaptation from Euripides, "Alceste" pits gods, ghosts, and superheroes against ordinary so-and-sos who make extraordinary sacrifices to try to tell the Future to consider itself. Objects are too brightly colored to see without squinting, while others remind us of people we're trying to forget. Boats and bathtubs roll in to where they have no business, and there's a terrible hissing that sounds like the end of things.

node.Event description: The play follows Mer Hicks and her "not quite right" daughter Dizzy as they weather a blizzard in Skagway, Alaska. Mer and Dizzy have been running from Mer's husband Hunter ever since he returned from the Special Forces, completely insane. Mer elicits the help of Jay, a half-blind fish canner from Skagway to kill Hunter so that Dizzy and Mer can finally stop running. When Jay fails to kill Hunt, and Mer fails to have Jay arrested - the blizzard blows in and everyone is locked inside a small bungalow on North Saints Lane.

www.chancetheater.com

WEST COAST PREMIERE!
"Sweet, Sexy, Neurotic friendly” – New York Times

It’s not me, it’s YOU! Submerse yourself in the modern dating scene with this dark comedy about falling into a relationship on the first date. Elliot has never had an online date before... at least not one that showed up. Susan has had far too many but would prefer not to discuss them. When they meet in a bar one night, all their personality flaws are revealed, along with a puppet, some modern dance and a desperation that may or may not be love.

When Hannah’s sister appears on their doorstep, she brings with her a feisty, renegade attitude and an illicit package that sends the family on an odyssey into some of the quirkier corners of Minneapolis, and into the heart of their deepest fears. Thursday, February 3, 2011

Director: Erica Gould
Dramaturg: Audrey Rosenberg
Actors: Angela Goethals, Colleen Werthmann, Rey Lucas, Jake Robards

node.Synopsis: Miguel Angel Flores, a 23-year-old homeless undocumented immigrant, falls through the ice of a pond in Central Park to his death.   No one reports him missing.  Erica, the only witnesses to the accident, is thrown into a strange world where she shuttles between her life, her memories, and historical events.  In the end, she finds herself in an unexpected place, and she must make a decision about living and dying.

node.Event description:
SLAC proudly presents the World Premiere of THE PERSIAN QUARTER by Kathleen Cahill (playwright of last season’s Charm.)
“…both a story told on a Persian carpet, and a piece of political history.” 
In Kathleen Cahill’s THE PERSIAN QUARTER, a diplomatic crisis and a chance encounter trigger revelations of a shared past. The play unfolds on the final day of the Iranian hostage crisis in 1980 Tehran with Anne, an American hostage and Shirin, an Iranian revolutionary student who is one of her captors. Thirty years later in New York City, their daughters, Emily and Azadeh, meet accidentally in an empty classroom at Columbia University during the visit of Iranian President Ahmadinejad.
Director: Alexandra Harbold
Company:Nell Gwynn, Deena Marie Manzanares, Shane Mozaffari, Joshua Thoemke

World premiere of Laura Eason's new play. It was originally developed through Steppenwolf's First Look Festival and is the first play to go onto the subscription series from that developmental program.

New England Premiere by David Wiener
1945: In the shattered city of Amsterdam, an obscure art dealer named Han van Meegeren is arrested and charged with treason for selling a Vermeer painting to the Nazis. But the investigation takes a bizarre turn when van Meegeren claims the Vermeer in question is his own forgery. The authorities challenge him to prove his ridiculous claim or face the gallows. Now, the master forger must create his greatest fake -- or lose his life.   The true story of the world's greatest art forger, Han van Meegeren.

node.Play title: Andy Warhol: Good for the Jews
node.Event description: Two nights. What's interesting to watch here is the way the piece moves through the Bay Area infrastructure among small and midsize producing and presenting companies. This micro-tour is something that happens with a degree of regularity in this region that is less prevalent in other communities of similar size.

This is the first workshop production of Joshua Conkel's "The Sluts of Sutton Drive." It will be fully staged with five performances at Ensemble Studio Theatre.
Synopsis: A working mother enrolls in a strip aerobics class only to realize she hates men. It's when she becomes addicted to drinking cleaning products that her life really begins to unravel.
World premiere of an outrageously dark comedy: It's late night in a biomedical research lab and careers are on the line for five high-strung grad students. Think The Office meets Lord of the Flies.
node.Synopsis: Five graduate students are stuck in the lab on a Sunday night in January. The youngest, Rachel, commits an act of unspeakable violence on a laboratory mouse. When the others confront her, she claims she was merely curious, and makes the point that they kill mice all the time, too. Though they return to work, the ugliness that underlies their work begins to manifest as the night goes on, leading to a Black Mass of laboratory science. It’s The Office meets Lord of the Flies. Tickets and information here: http://www.manbitesdogtheater.org/354/

node.Event description:
Seagull
By Anton Chekhov
New version by Libby Appel
From a literal translation by Allison Horsley
Directed by Jasson Minadakis
Experience a sleek, sexy production of this 20th Century classic in a world premiere adaptation by former Oregon Shakespeare Festival Artistic Director Libby Appel. When the famed actress Arkadina returns to her country estate with her young lover, the writer Trigorin, the romantic entanglements, artistic conflicts and jealousies that erupt threaten to tear her family apart. With newly discovered material from Chekhov's original manuscripts and a fresh perspective on one of theater's most elegant and enduring stories, this is Chekhov like you've never seen him before.
A full-length, two-act play set in a legalized brothel in Nevada.   Cast of seven women; strong roles for entire ensemble.  Directed by Meghan Beals McCarthy; Dramaturgy by Robert Koon.

The Sluts of Sutton Drive
by Joshua Conkel
directed by Lila Neugebauer
A working mother enrolls in a strip aerobics class only to realize she hates men. It’s when she becomes addicted to drinking cleaning products that her life really begins to unravel.
with Denny Bess*+, Graeme Gillis*,
Megan Hill+, Justin Noble,
and Amy Staats*+

Ten years ago in Lewiston, Idaho, Brent and Andy shared their secrets. Brent now drifts from one college town to the next, lecturing and playing reinventions of Beethoven's Pathetique. The story and the music shift in time across a decade, deconstructing the cliches of a "coming out" story and revealing how the boys' relationship caused Andy's father, Mark, to fulfill his own obsession. Samuel D. Hunter is a rising star in the American theater whose plays will see five different productions across the country this season. Join us for this co-world premiere (with the Phoenix Theatre in Indianapolis), the first full production of a Hunter play in his home state.
Regional premiere, directed by Seth Rozin. Dramaturgy by Rebecca Wright.

BLACK TIE
59E59 Theaters
January 25 - March 20, 2011
A World Premiere comedy by A.R. Gurney
Directed by Mark Lamos
Father of the groom, Curtis, simply wants to make a memorable toast. But before he is able to raise his glass, he must defend the time-honored ways of his past, including his attire. Cultures clash when a surprise guest is announced, threatening to throw convention out the window. Curtis finds that balancing the standards of his late father and the needs of his future family may prove too messy for a black tie affair.
With Ari Brand, Daniel Davis, Gregg Edelman, Carolyn McCormick, Elvy Yost
Tues-Wed 7, Thurs-Sat 8, Sat 2, Wed 2 (2/16, 2/23), Sun 3 (1/30, 2/6, 2/13, 3/20)
RUN TIME: 90 minutes, no intermission.
Black Tie is made possible, in part, through the generous support of The Blanche & Irving Laurie Foundation.
The set of Black Tie has been underwritten by donors to Primary Stages 2010 End-of-Year Campaign.

THE CUSTODIAN: How do you choose between two impossible choices?  Dave lives a normal if economically challenged life as a custodian with well-founded hopes of becoming a high school English teacher.  When his developmentally challenged brother Mitch gets involved in a high profile murder, Dave is confronted with a nightmarish decision.  Regardless of his choice, everyone and everything will be changed forever.
6:30PM - FREE READING
THE CUSTODIAN was developed at the 2010 Seven Devils Playwrights Conference in McCall, Idaho

node.Related Theater: The New York One-Minute Play Festival
node.Event description:
The New York One-Minute Play Festival & The New Brunswick Theater Festival
Present
The New Jersey One-Minute Play Festival
Jan. 22th & 23th, 2011 @8:00pm
Van Dyck Hall, Room 211 on the Rutgers University College Avenue Campus
16 Seminary Place
New Brunswick, NJ, 08901 
For info visit: http://www.newbrunswicktheaterfestival.org and www.oneminuteplays.wordpress.com 
Tickets are $15 at the door, on a first come, first served basis
Proceeds benefit The New Brunswick Theater Festival’s community-based and educational programming for their 2011 summer season
It's theater boiled down to its essence. Sixty Seconds from lights up to lights down. Curated by Dominic D'Andrea, the program will present 50 new one-minute plays by some of the most exciting New Jersey Playwrights and theatre professionals, the Rutgers University theatre community, and members of the New Brunswick Theater Festival. 
The 2011 New Jersey One-Minute Play Festival Playwrights Are:
Ben Clawson, Michael Crisculo, Tom Diggs, Richard Dresser, Bryan Dykstra, Peter Handy, Jon Hoche, Lisa Huberman, Lanna Joffrey, Stacie Lents, Josh Levine, Mariah MacCarthy, James McLindon, Carrie Louise Nutt, Matt Schatz, Robert Shaffron, Crystal Skillman, Ann-Giselle Spiegler, Brendon Votipka, David Lee White, Webb Wilcoxen. 
Directed by: 
John P. Keller (co-artistic director of the New Brunswick Theatre Festival & Rutgers Alum)
Karin Shook (co-founder of the Chicago Directors Lab)
Louis Wells (NJ-based freelance director & Rutgers Alum)
David Winitsky (NJ-based freelance director)
Dominic D’Andrea (curator/producer of the One-Minute Play Festival, NYC-based director)
About The New York One-Minute Play Festival: Created by director Dominic D'Andrea, the New York One-Minute Play Festival started as a short-form theatre experiment in 2007 at the Brick Theater in Williamsburg seeking to distill a theatrical event down to its most immediate and elemental form of storytelling. It continues to serve as a playwright-focused community event, bringing artists and community together to promote the spirit of radical inclusion and invite artists to dialogue about an emerging form of theatre.  Past New York festivals have included: The Brick Theater in Williamsburg (also partnering with Monarch Theatre 2007); TBG Arts Theatre (2008); HERE Arts Center as part of the Autumn Artist Lodge (2009); and at Astoria Performing Arts Center (2010.) This past year the festival started producing nationally partnering with theatres who either have playwright-focused or community-based missions: East LA Rep (Los Angeles, CA, Dec 2010), The Playwrights Foundation (San Francisco, CA, Dec 2010), and The New Brunswick Theatre Festival (NJ, Jan 2010.) Festivals are also being planned for Washington, DC, Chicago, and Minneapolis for 2011. 
Over the past 4 years, the New York One Minute Play Festival has produced over 350 new sixty-second plays. Notable alumni include: Rajiv Joseph (2009 Pulitzer Nominee), Kristopher Diaz (2009 Pulitzer Nominee), Michael John Garces (Artistic Director, Cornerstone Theatre, LA), Mike Daisey (famed Monologist), Kyle Jarrow (Obie Award winner), Caridad Svich (Founder, NoPassport), &  Qui Nguyen (Playwright & Co-Artistic Director of the Obie Award Winning, Vampire Cowboys Theatre Company), & Erik Ehn (Head of Playwriting, Brown University.)
The New Brunswick Theater Festival's mission is to cultivate a hip, mindful, and inclusive Hub City community of artists and audiences empowered to create inspired and inspiring art by combining exciting, free, professional performances with a dynamic educational outreach component. Since its inception, the New Brunswick Theater Festival has provided free theater to new audiences, given young artists their first glimpse into the world of Shakespeare, and provided young artists with training alongside professional mentors. As we grow we hope you will join us in continuing our mission and helping to stimulate the living and working artistic environment that is New Brunswick, New Jersey.

node.Play title: Agnes Under the Big Top, a tall tale
node.Event description: #New Play Festival reading of 'Agnes Under the Big Top, a tall tale'
node.Synopsis: Aditi Brennan Kapil's play AGNES UNDER THE BIG TOP, A TALL TALE was first produced in a National New Play Network Rolling World Premiere at Mixed Blood Theatre (Minneapolis, MN), Long Wharf Theatre (New Haven, CT), and Borderlands (Tucson, AZ) with support from the Continued Life of New Plays Fund.  www.nnpn.org // Against the subterranean rhythms of a subway train, an itinerant subway busker, a Liberian home care worker, a former Bulgarian ringmaster and his wife, and an Indian call center escapee find and redefine themselves in today’s America. [Source: http://www.mixedblood.com/mainstage/agnes]

node.Event description: Reading of a new play by Patrick Gabridge.  (at 3pm, Saturday, January 22)
World premiere of THE BOYS ROOM.

World Premiere of Stephen Metcalfe's TRAGEDY OF THE COMMONS.  "Dakin Adams, a retired school teacher, spends his days writing and sending his thoughts – his blogs – out in the void that is the internet. His wife, Macy, walks the dogs and gardens. It would seem the only thing they have in common anymore is their home, their memories and their love of “the view” – the Pacific Ocean as seen from the back deck of the house. But now their neighbor is selling and the new owner is coming in to tear down and rebuild – build “up” – and the view – and the fragile relationship of two people – is in ever increasing jeopardy. "

node.Synopsis: Welcome to the world of Jennifer Samuels, who has just discovered that she is her own twin. Inspired by a real-life horror story, CHIMERA takes you on a journey from the frontiers of modern science to the seeds of ancient mythology.

node.Event description: A devised play conceived by Beth Wilmurt and directed by Mark Jackson.  Performed by Christopher Kuckenbaker, Jake Rodriguez, and Beth Wilmurt.
node.Synopsis: The Companion Piece is an experimentally devised work, which is created by the actors and designers themselves during rehearsals and workshops. Conceived by Beth Wilmurt and directed by Mark Jackson, this vaudeville-style play grapples with questions of survival, success, and identity.

node.Play title: The Puppeteers, A Wonderful Weirdness in OZ
node.Event description:
World Premiere Production of The Puppeteers, A Wonderful Weirdness in OZ, created and performed by Zuppa del Giorno.
Inspired by the idea of commedia dell'arte meeting the characters from the Wizard of Oz, it is a madcap comic escapade for audiences of all ages that skips lightly through generation gaps, laughs at hard times, and finds magic in the mundane.
A World Premiere Conceived by Beth Wilmurt Directed by Mark Jackson Starring Beth Wilmurt, Christopher Kuckenbaker, and Jake Rodriguez.

Staged Reading of Early Poe by Dan Trujillo
A funny, tumultuous, and slightly surreal look at the family life of young Edgar Allan Poe, his relationships with his mother, his step-father, his tutor, his first love, and his creative yearnings.

node.Play title: THE WALK ACROSS AMERICA FOR MOTHER EARTH
node.Event description: Full production of new play with songs by Taylor Mac which tells the story of a nine-month protest walk from New York to the Nevada Nuclear Test Site.
node.Synopsis: In 1992, one hundred activists (including Taylor Mac) set out to protest the actions of the U.S. government by embarking on a symbolic Walk Across America for Mother Earth. Told in a pastiche of disparate styles, this lively musical romp lovingly skewers the foibles of activists while celebrating our shared urge to improve the world with direct action.

In JAR FLY, a teenaged Iris Spears teeters on the brink of maturity when an event shatters her innocence—and changes her life forever. In RAIN, a 34-year-old Iris flees a collapsing marriage to return home to Texas and the comfort of her mother's embrace, only to find that the once-solid ground has shifted beneath her feet. And in GHOSTSTORY, a surprise visit from her estranged husband forces Iris to confront the past and the ghosts that have continued to haunt her. The trilogy is inspired by the rhythm of the cicada—a part of Iris' young life in the south—the insect that emerges every 17 years to take wing.

node.Event description: This was a public reading of the play following a weekend of rehearsal with a full cast. This whole process was part of a "completion commission" that was aimed at supporting the writer in finishing a rewrite of a play that had had two prior productions but which Heather felt was, as yet, unfinished. The commission, the design retreat, and the reading moved that forward for her.

Maya and Me is a story about the friendship between two women that meet by chance and begin to develop a relationship that not only confuses those around them, but causes both women to see their lives in a different light, and see themselves through each other’s eyes. They learn to lean and depend on one another. Relationships are about giving and taking, wanting and needing, but what they soon find is that one will need the other just a little bit more.

Friday, January 14, 2011

with Rey Lucas

node.Event description:
A reimagining of the myth of Ariadne, Theseus and the Minotaur in a postmodern exploration, Bone to Pick received its world premiere at Cutting Ball in 2008. The San Francisco Chronicle called Paige Rogers’ performance “riveting.” For this restaging, Rogers will reprise her tour-de-force role of Ariadne as a waitress in a diner, 3000 years after she was first left on the island of Naxos, now a deserted U.S. Army base.
Accompanying Bone to Pick is a newly commissioned companion piece called Diadem, also by Chan, which examines the day that Ariadne is abandoned by her young husband. Together, these two original works tell the complete story of Ariadne’s epic romance.
Part of Madcap Players' Winter Carnival Festival at the H Street Playhouse

THE WAR SINCE EVE by Kim Carney - The World Premiere of a knockout comedy from the playwright of "Moonglow" and "The Home Team"! On the eve of receiving the Presidential Medal of Freedom, women's rights pioneer and bawdy, outspoken feminist Roxie Firestone has a dilemma. As the mother of two grown daughters - Milty, her put-upon assistant, and the estranged Tara - she wouldn't win any Mother of the Year awards. When Tara returns and Milty threatens to jump ship, she must decide which is more important, sisterhood or motherhood? Starring Henrietta Hermelin, Sarab Kamoo and Leah Smith, directed by David Wolber.
New York Premiere directed by Erica Schmidt.

node.Play title: When We Go Upon the Sea
node.Event description: A stripped down production of Lee Blessing's WHEN WE GO UPON THE SEA, part of Profile Theatre's 2010-11 season focusing on Blessing's work.
node.Synopsis: Commissioned by InterAct in 2008 through its 20/20 New Play Commission program, WHEN WE GO UPON THE SEA is a provocative new play by Tony Award nominated playwright Lee Blessing, author of A WALK IN THE WOODS, WHORES, and GOING TO ST. IVES. Set in a high-end hotel room at The Hague, WHEN WE GO UPON THE SEA imagines former President George W. Bush on the eve of his trial for international war crimes. Tended to by an inscrutable Dutch butler and an alluring masseuse, the President embarks on a long night of drinking, joking, and ruminating, taking the audience through a deep exploration of how we regard our leaders - loving them, fearing them, unintentionally deifying them. WHEN WE GO UPON THE SEA examines an American populace that has grown strikingly complacent in the wake of extraordinary global challenges, exposing one of the world’s most intriguing and influential conflicts: the battle between the elected leader of the free world and a democracy of millions. [Source: http://www.interacttheatre.org/2009-2010-feature-3.html]

node.Event description:
Sometimes opposites attract. And sometimes your angry boyfriend gift-wraps a bloody appendage and leaves it in a public park on Valentine’s Day. Love moves in mysterious ways.
"Bear Foot in the Park" was directed by Lila Neugebauer and premiered as part of The Tens.
The Tens is an annual evening of new ten-minute plays performed and produced by members of the Actors Theatre of Louisville's Apprentice/Intern Company.  Plays featured in The Tens are new works selected from the National Ten-Minute Play Contest, and include a diverse range of pieces by nine playwrights.

"The book, Jim!  Where’s the book? "
Jim, a sincere young office worker in a publishing firm’s incineration department, finds hope in the biography of a young prince who travels around the universe by net. In this oppressive Orwellian dystopia, can Jim convince his colleague, Jack, to see the truth behind a closed door—before the stress alarm goes off and it’s too late?
"1984 and The Little Prince" was directed by Amy Attaway and premiered as part of The Tens.
The Tens is an annual evening of new ten-minute plays performed and produced by members of the Actors Theatre of Louisville's Apprentice/Intern Company.  Plays featured in The Tens are new works selected from the National Ten-Minute Play Contest, and include a diverse range of pieces by nine playwrights.

Rodney hung himself in his office, Jefferson won’t leave the break room, Ryan’s gonna be a Dad and Rebecca can’t finish her sentence.  All that’s left in the fridge are the leftovers of the recently fired. When all you want is to share a kitchen, a remote control and a mattress full of bed bugs with someone, how do you approach the project of honesty?
"Famished" was directed by Zach Chotzen-Freund and premiered as part of The Tens.
The Tens is an annual evening of new ten-minute plays performed and produced by members of the Actors Theatre of Louisville Apprentice/Intern Company.  Plays featured in The Tens are new works selected from the National Ten-Minute Play Contest, and include a diverse range of pieces by nine playwrights.

In a quiet West Virginia attic in the summer of 1935, two friends find themselves standing at the edge between innocence and experience. In the wake of an unexpected tragedy, Luce and Daniel are suddenly free to acknowledge the long-unspoken connection that binds them to each other—but what must they give up to be together?
"From the River" was directed by Rachel Paul and premiered as part of The Tens.
The Tens is an annual evening of new ten-minute plays performed and produced by members of the Actors Theatre of Louisville Apprentice/Intern Company.  Plays featured in The Tens are new works selected from the National Ten-Minute Play Contest, and include a diverse range of pieces by nine playwrights.

node.Play title: Holy Matrimony! (And Other Things To Do in Lieu of Saving the World)
node.Event description:
Best friends Travis and Mark have taken a break from fighting crime to celebrate Mark’s nuptials, but news of nearby super-villainy threatens to disrupt the happy occasion.  Holy Matrimony! is a comedy about friendship, loyalties, and the kinds of heroes we choose to become. 
"Holy Matrimony! (And Other Things To Do In Lieu of Saving the World)" was directed by Ian Frank and premiered as part of The Tens.
The Tens is an annual evening of new ten-minute plays performed and produced by members of the Actors Theatre of Louisville Apprentice/Intern Company.  Plays featured in The Tens are new works selected from the National Ten-Minute Play Contest, and include a diverse range of pieces by nine playwrights.

In this rhythmic display of family dysfunction, Wendy has been sent home from school with a parasite growing out of her head. What ensues builds on the old adage: the trouble with normal is that it always gets worse.
"Hygiene" was directed by Greg Maupin and premiered as part of The Tens.
The Tens is an annual evening of new ten-minute plays performed and produced by members of the Actors Theatre of Louisville Apprentice/Intern Company.  Plays featured in The Tens are new works selected from the National Ten-Minute Play Contest, and include a diverse range of pieces by nine playwrights.

Two strangers meet just before the end of the world. What does it feel like to know there is no tomorrow?
"Kiss" was directed by Ian Frank and premiered as part of The Tens.
The Tens is an annual evening of new ten-minute plays performed and produced by members of the Actors Theatre of Louisville Apprentice/Intern Company.  Plays featured in The Tens are new works selected from the National Ten-Minute Play Contest, and include a diverse range of pieces by nine playwrights.

Molly Forge, the proprietor of a classy lady’s dress shop, discovers that her hair is rapidly receding from the nape of her neck and proceeding down the front of her face.  As disaster creeps down her forehead, Molly decides she must tell a certain man she loves him before it’s too late. 
"The Last Hat, a Tragedy" was directed by Michael Legg and premiered as part of The Tens.
The Tens is an annual evening of new ten-minute plays performed and produced by members of the Actors Theatre of Louisville Apprentice/Intern Company.  Plays featured in The Tens are new works selected from the National Ten-Minute Play Contest, and include a diverse range of pieces by nine playwrights.

On Zoe’s first Thanksgiving home from college, she and her best friend Skyler find that differences that had seemed insignificant, now create chasms… A funny, sad look at growing up—and growing apart. 
"That First Fall" was directed by Lila Neugebauer and premiered as part of The Tens.
The Tens is an annual evening of new ten-minute plays performed and produced by members of the Actors Theatre of Louisville Apprentice/Intern Company.  Plays featured in The Tens are new works selected from the National Ten-Minute Play Contest, and include a diverse range of pieces by nine playwrights.
A comedy about Modernism,  Method, and true love.

node.Synopsis: Brenna’s soulmate is missing, but finding him is hard when she can’t stop channeling the Internet. Gale tries to help, but she’s got her own problems and her printer’s out of toner. Both women, an anti-Tech cult, the FBI, and the Internet itself will be involved before it’s over, and the city will never be the same. An explosive comedy exploring how we connect when we’re always connected,  and just what’s left when the universe hits the delete key.

node.Event description: Premiere production
node.Synopsis: In 1990, author Lynn Schooler was a guide in Juneau when he met the Japanese wildlife photographer, Michio Hoshino. The two shared a passion for writing, photography, Alaska’s wild places and together began a search to find and photograph the legendary blue or glacier bear, a very are color variation of black bear. Before they could find a blue bear, Hoshino was tragically killed by a Siberian grizzly, and Schooler dedicated himself to getting their photograph to honor his friend. THE BLUE BEAR follows Schooler’s tale of learning to trust again through his stunningly intimate portrait of a remarkable friendship. The production combines Schooler’s text with Hoshino’s images.
